title: USS Baya
text:
USS "Baya" (SS/AGSS-318), a <a href="Balao%20class%20submarine">"Balao"-class</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a>, was a ship of the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> named for the <a href="Gulf%20grouper">baya</a>.
"Baya" was launched on 2 January 1944 by <a href="Electric%20Boat">Electric Boat</a> Co., <a href="Groton%2C%20Conn.">Groton, Conn.</a>; sponsored by Mrs. Charles C. Kirkpatrick, and commissioned on 20 May 1944, <a href="Commander">Commander</a> A. H. Holtz in command.
World War II.
"Baya" arrived at <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> in August 1944. During 23 August 1944 – 25 July 1945 she completed five war patrols in the <a href="South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea</a>, <a href="Gulf%20of%20Siam">Gulf of Siam</a>, <a href="Java%20Sea">Java Sea</a>, and <a href="Philippine%20Sea">Philippine Sea</a>. "Baya" sank four Japanese vessels totaling 8855 tons and an 8407-ton passenger-cargo ship in conjunction with .
"Baya" departed <a href="Subic%20Bay">Subic Bay</a>, <a href="Philippine%20Islands">Philippine Islands</a>, in September 1945 and arrived at <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco</a> on 24 September. Shortly thereafter she began inactivation and on 14 May 1946 went out of commission in reserve at <a href="Mare%20Island%20Naval%20Shipyard">Mare Island Naval Shipyard</a>.
"Baya" received four <a href="battle%20star">battle star</a>s for her <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> service.
Research submarine.
"Baya" was recommissioned 10 February 1948 and converted to an electronics experimental submarine. Reclassified Auxiliary Research Submarine, AGSS-318, 12 August 1949, "Baya" conducted experiments for the <a href="Naval%20Electronics%20Laboratory">Naval Electronics Laboratory</a> <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, Calif.</a>, participated in local operations near San Diego and served with the joint American-Canadian Task Force gathering scientific data off western <a href="Canada">Canada</a> in November and December 1948. During July–September 1949 she made a cruise to the <a href="Arctic">Arctic</a> to gather valuable scientific data in the <a href="Bering%20Sea">Bering</a> and <a href="Chukchi%20Sea">Chukchi Sea</a>s. Between July and October 1955 she was deployed to Pearl Harbor on further experimental research.
"Baya" was used as a <a href="testbed">testbed</a> for two early <a href="sonar">sonar</a> <a href="transducer">transducer</a> arrays which markedly changed her appearance. The first arrangement of 196 transducers in a 14×14 array was attached to the former gun mount abaft the conning tower, facing starboard and surrounded by a fairwater resembling a second conning tower.
After the first array and fairwater were removed, "Baya" was completely reworked at Mare Island Naval Shipyard during 1958 and 1959 to test the second array, called <a href="LORAD">LORAD</a> (for LOng RAnge Detection). The forward <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s were removed and replaced by a blunt bow containing the forward-facing transducer array. A <a href="mushroom%20anchor">mushroom anchor</a> was installed in the bottom of the hull; and a section was added between the former forward torpedo room and the forward battery compartment, with quarters for twelve scientists. These modifications increased her overall length to , and her submerged displacement to approximately 2,600 tons. Her maximum speed was reduced to .<a href="http%3A//www.subnet.com/FLEET/ss318.htm"></a>
"Baya" was decommissioned and struck from the <a href="Naval%20Register">Naval Register</a>, 30 October 1972, and sold for scrapping, 12 October 1973.
